title: How to Activate the Virtual Keyboard on a Mac

steps.title: Open your Mac's System Preferences.
steps.content: Open your Mac's System Preferences. To do this, click the System Preferences icon in your Dock or Applications folder.

steps.title: Select the Keyboard icon.
steps.content: Select the Keyboard icon. If you're using an older version of the Mac software (Mountain Lion and earlier), it won't be called "Keyboard". Click on "Language & Text," instead.

steps.title: Click on the Input Sources tab.
steps.content: Click on the Input Sources tab.

steps.title: Add a language/region option if needed.
steps.content: Add a language/region option if needed. If you already have an appropriate keyboard option in the list (e.g. U.S. or British), then proceed to the next step. If you don't, click + and scroll through the list to select the language you want. Then click Add . Even keyboards from the same language but different regions can have different layouts, so make sure you're using the one you're familiar with.

steps.title: Check the Show Input menu in menu bar option towards the bottom.
steps.content: Check the Show Input menu in menu bar option towards the bottom. It may be selected automatically or already, but if it isn't, check it.

steps.title: Locate the Input icon on your Mac menu bar, towards the right-hand side.
steps.content: Locate the Input icon on your Mac menu bar, towards the right-hand side. It may look like a keyboard/symbol icon or it may show the flag of the language you've selected. Click on it and select Show Keyboard Viewer to view the onscreen keyboard.

steps.title: Use your cursor to select any of the onscreen keyboard keys just as you would on a regular keyboard.
steps.content: Use your cursor to select any of the onscreen keyboard keys just as you would on a regular keyboard. You can type with the virtual keyboard in any location on your screen: just click within the desired text box/area and then click on the virtual keyboard, one key at a time, to type. You can also move the virtual keyboard around as necessary to keep it out of the way. It will float on top of your other windows.
